title: How to Shoot in Direct Sunlight

steps.headline: Take it into the shade.
steps.description: See if you can find a tree nearby. Of course, this only works when your subject is portable.

steps.headline: Create your own shade.
steps.description: Use your body, someone else, cardstock, or anything that will work.

steps.headline: Use Fill in Flash.
steps.description: You will need to learn how to do that with your own camera, but using a flash when you are outside, will help counter the bright sun and the unfortunate shadows that it creates.

steps.headline: Use a reflector to help counter the bright sun and its shadows.
Change your perspective.
steps.description: Shoot straight down or straight up. This changes the angle of the bright sun that you are dealing with.

steps.headline: Use a lens hood.
steps.description: This helps protect your lens from the brightness of the sun.

steps.headline: Learn about filters that you can use to alleviate the brightness and compensate for the color/temperature difference.
steps.description: Polarizing and neutral density filters are some good ones that help with your photography.

steps.headline: Set your white balance.
steps.description: If you set it, then all of your shots will have identical white balance. That way, even if you have to adjust settings, you can apply the same ones to all of the photographs.

steps.headline: Shoot RAW.
steps.description: This allows you to have more to work with. With today's software, you can still do a lot with your JPG images, but RAW gives you a little more to work with.

steps.headline: Use spot metering.
steps.description: This will help your camera 'focus' on what it needs to.

steps.headline: Change the time of day.
steps.description: Instead of going out there at noon, try going during the 'golden hour'. This is the hour right before the sun sets and rises.

steps.headline: Use the sunlight and shoot silhouettes.
steps.description: You can make some stunning images doing that.
